title: about Me
text:
I hold a Master’s degree in Epidemiology and Biostatistics and have over five years of experience collaborating with clinicians, epidemiologists, and public health teams.
My role often involves translating complex statistical results into actionable scientific insights.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
This project examines neighborhood-level socioeconomic predictors of late HIV diagnosis. I served as the lead biostatistician, responsible for analytic strategy, modeling decisions, and interpretation.

All data shown are simulated or de-identified.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
This project examines neighborhood-level socioeconomic predictors of late HIV diagnosis. I served as the lead biostatistician, responsible for analytic strategy, modeling decisions, and interpretation.

All data shown are simulated or de-identified.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Data

Outcome: Late diagnosis (binary)
Covariates: age at diagnosis, race, neighborhood poverty
Clustering unit: health district

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Statistical Methods
A multilevel logistic regression model was used to account for clustering of individuals within health districts.
Modeling choices were guided by: - Public health interpretability - Stability under sparse geographic data - Alignment with study objectives

library(lme4)

fit <- glmer(
  late_dx ~ age_dx + race + poverty + (1 | district),
  data = dat,
  family = binomial
)

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Interpretation
Higher neighborhood poverty was associated with increased odds of late HIV diagnosis after adjusting for individual-level factors.
Racial disparities persisted, suggesting that neighborhood context alone does not fully explain observed differences.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Analytical Decisions & Challenges

Geographic unit: Zip-code–level models were unstable due to sparse counts; district-level aggregation improved model convergence.
Missing data: Multiple imputation was used instead of complete-case analysis to reduce bias.
Model complexity: Penalized models were explored but not selected due to interpretability concerns for stakeholders.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Impact

Findings informed geographically targeted HIV testing strategies.
Results were presented to public health leadership.
Supported a peer-reviewed manuscript submission.

title: Neighborhood-Level Predictors of Late HIV Diagnosis
text:
Reproducibility
Analyses were conducted in R using Quarto for reproducible reporting and version control via Git.

title: Home
text:
I am a senior biostatistician with experience supporting clinical, epidemiologic, and public health research. My work focuses on rigorous study design, transparent statistical modeling, and reproducible reporting.



Regression modeling (GLM, GLMM)
Survival analysis
Penalized regression (LASSO)
Multiple imputation
Neighborhood- and multilevel analyses




R, SAS, Python, Quarto, Git
